the moment that Peter had tapped the screen (which had actually turned out to be a touch-screen despite ho old the machine looked in appearance), two large, black buttons popped out of the top of the machine next to the power button. On them, in chipped, old looking white stenciled labels were the words 'Traditional' and 'Immersive'.

"Traditional and Immersive? Eugene, what did the box say about these again? I think we should all know what we're getting into before we just make a decision that affects everyone" Judy said, giving her boyfriend a glaring side-eye through her heavy eye-liner and hopefully trying to intimidate the normally caring jock from making any other brash, jerkish decisions.

Of course, Peter just thought it looked kinda hot, but he played up the 'whipped boyfriend' act so that the gang would stop being mad at him. And he was a little confused as to why, exactly, he'd just batted Eugene's hands away and just selected sports as the game type. He wasn't typically a jerk like that, especially to his friend (who needed all the help he could get getting out of that nerdy little shell of his), and the feeling of just being...compelled to tap the screen left him with a weird after-taste in his mouth. It tasted like...green? But the feeling (and taste) quickly passed.

"Sorry, guys. Guess I just have football on the brain. I've, uh, been a little worried about what's gonna happen in the fall with the, uh, Coronavirus and all. Kinda my scholarship thing" Peter said with a shrug and a sheepish grin, and hoped that it was a sympathetic enough excuse. He was rewarded with Judy's glare softening just a bit.

"Well, like, it's actually called Covid-19. Coronavirus was just the, um, term for like when it just gets discovered in a human and stuff" Lindsey said with a knowing nod. She wanted to tag on how, like, totally not cool it was for Peter to have done that but she relented. She didn't fully believe his apology but Pete was definitely at the top of the list for jocks that had surprised her for not playing to the stereotype. But it was a pretty short list.

"It's okay Pete I, uh, just want us to have a good time" Eugene said with a thumbs up and a smile that looked every letter of the word 'forced'. Eugene wasn't really a sports guy at all, with baseball being the only one he could really tolerate (mainly because he had fond memories of going to Dodger's Stadium with his mom and grandpa when he was a little kid), but Peter had been a good friend to him. A slip up here and there wasn't enough to just end their friendship like that.

And Judy knew that Peter clearly wasn't truly sorry for making the decision for everyone, but unlike Lindsey, actually believed his excuse. Peter, in private, could actually be something of a mess when it came to his scholarship stuff. The big palooka was smart and if pressed could probably find a major to support him if they DID cancel his scholarship due to the pandemic...But despite his family being pretty well off, Peter had often gone on rants about how his dad wouldn't financially support him if he messed it up. That was, after all, part of the reason Peter had come all the way out here to Colorado rather than attending some expensive East Coast Ivy League school. Cheaper tuition and a smaller student loan.

And of course, if all that hadn't happened, Judy never would have met her darling buffoon. There was no telling what would have happened if he hadn't been there to support her and give her the confidence to actually live HER life, not that stuffy, oppressive life that had been built for her back home. The one she'd run away from. So she was a little more willing to accept Peter's apology, even if she was biased. But then the moment passed and she cleared her throat once more.

"So, what do we do to get started, Eugene? What's the difference between the modes again?" The top-heavy and curvy goth girl asked the overweight freshman once more.

"Oh! Uh, I, uh..." Eugene's eyes went wide as he fumbled for the lid of the box the strange R2D2-esque game had come in, "It, uh...Well Traditional is just like a normal board game and Immersive is more like, uh, Dungeons and Dragons?"

"Nah, with sports it'll be more like Stratego or something" Peter chimed in from the couch.

"Or yeah. That." Eugene nodded, not really knowing WHAT exactly Stratego outside of the version Peter owned was from the 70s and in dire need of replacment. But then the geek sputtered as Lindsey reached over and brushed her hand against his and, like a cat, swiftly swiped the box lid out of Eugene's hands as she took it for herself.

"So, um..." Lindsey brushed a few rainbow-colored strands of hair from her face as he brow furrowed in concentration, "It totally comes pre-loaded with some, um, presets but we can set it up to play like, however we want. We just push the button and then we, like, get to choose our game pieces. Then we just type in the piece names into that tiny little keyboard and hit enter and the game will start. Oh, wait, that's just for Immersive. IF we go, um, traditional and stuff, we gotta choose a game length but it'll totally be conformed to what game we want. Like baseball!"

"Of football" Peter added in, causing everyone to frown once more.

"...Or yeah. Football"

"Well I just think we need to choose something that EVERYONE will enjoy. Not just the people that know a thing or two about sports" Judy said as she leaned over to inspect the game's lid. That was a LOT of text and it was small and faded and aftera moment she just gave up trying to read it from this distance. Instead she just naturally fell into the role of peacemaker; knowing that compromise was usually the best way forward after having spent her entire life unknowingly miserable at having everything decided for her.

"Well I can teach you guys how to play Stratego if traditional is like that. It's SUPER easy" Peter offered, his voice more than just hinting that he wanted it to happen.

"I wonder what Immersive is like. Like do we actually have to, um, play sports and junk?" Lindsey said, softly biting a nail and pretending not to notice Eugene shifting in his seat. Specifically shifting his pants in his seat as his face turned red.

After a few moments of Peter-dominant discussion with a dialogue back and forth about each version of the game and then Lindsey passing the game lid around so that everyone had a chance to look over the rules and differences between game modes (the rainbow-blonde noticed that everyone had a slightly different interpretation of the rules as they read them, as if the faded text was altering itself slightly of, like, something), the group took a vote and chose to play in...

1432.content:
"So how does 'sports' work in like, immersive mode?" Lindsey asked as she pushed in the 'Immersive' button on top of the game machine. She wasn't particularly thrilled about the prospect of playing an actual sport. She may have been a cheerleader but that was because it was fun and because it looked good when she had been applying for the sorority. They may have been a little less 'stereotypical' to some other organizations, but Gamma Upsilon Rho Lambda still had it's hang-ups in regards to traditional gender roles.

The big black button finally locked into place with a click and there was a metallic buzzing sound before the game boomed "SPORTS: IMMERSIVE MODE CHOSEN. PLAYERS CHOOSE THEIR AVATARS. PRESS START TO BEGIN"

"Ugh, doesn't this thing have a volume control!?" Eugene winced as the horribly distorted voice rolled over the group again.

"You need to come to more games, dude. You get used to loud noises" Peter shrugged as he sat on the edge of the couch, his foot tapping in excitement. And here he thought Judy's whole 'let's get Eugene and Lindsey together!' plan was going to be boring. He wasn't sure what this weirdo machine was going to do, but it was still sports, right?

That was when a bitter, burning smell began to fill the dorm's common room.

"Oh no! Did it short out?" Judy cried as she pinched her nose shut as the stink tried to invade her nostrils. Eugene and Peter did the same thing, while Lindsey, while clearly not enjoying the smell, wasn't alarmed by the tiny smoke trail rising out of a tiny ventilation port in the side of the outrageously detailed machine.

"Nah Ju-Ju, this is what a 3D printer smells like!"

"No way, there's no way something this old could have one of those in it!" Eugene said, leaning in close and taking out his phone, flipping the flashlight on as he tried to peer around at the darkened interior.

"Yeah huh! 3D printers existed in the 80s y'know! They were just, like, SUPER big and totes rare. And I've NEVER seen one this small! Genie, you could be sitting on something you could sell to like, the tech lab or something!" Lindsey, said, pressing her face in close to Eugene's as well as she was and had been DYING to take the machine apart and look at all the neat custom analogue tech. That was what she loved about old machines, they were always different! Always new! Now everything was so software reliant and standardized. It made making some money on the side building rigs for people easier, but Lindsey definitely missed the days back in Seattle where she'd find old retro-tech and take it apart and build new stuff with it.

Meanwhile, Eugene simply tried not to start stuttering again as he felt the sorority girl's smooth cheek-flesh rub against his own.

And then with a loud DING, a tray slid out from the side of the game console, and in it was a pile of highly detailed plastic figures of a variety of colors (even beyond that of Lindsey's own rainbow-filled locks), and all of them were sports-related. In the center of the mass of figurines however, was a small stand that held what was clearly a red football player, a large blue pom-pom, a strange yellow figure that was some kind of mascot, and...a green water bottle?

"SEE! Even the game wants us to play football!" Peter practically squealed as he reached forward to grab the red piece, only have Judy bat away his hand.

"Don't you dare, mister! You've been a butthead this whole time, so as of now I am officially banishing you from making choices for us!" Judy fumed, planting a black-tipped finger on the (admittingly hunky) chest of her boyfriend and pointing to the far end of the couch.

"Aw, but Jude-"

"NO BUTTS! and if you can't play nice, you won't get mine either" Judy said with a indignant huff, crossing her arms across her substantial chest and sticking her nose in the air, much to the delight of Lindsey who broke out into a fit of giggles while Eugene just looked away out of politeness, choosing to instead inspect the other figurines in the tray.

There was an abundance of them, all nicely arranged into individual sections that were clearly labelled. The one with the basketball and, well, the lanky figure in the jersey shared a slot with another set of pompoms, this time yellow, and a green mascot. There was one with a baseball player holding a bat, a glove, a baseball, and then finally some kind weird...cage helmet looking thing?

'Pete probably know what it is' Eugene thought with a shrug as he ignored the rather comical domestic antics that were taking place on the couch, egged on by Lindsey. There was another one for hockey, soccer, boxing, even wrestling! In fact, this tray wasn't even all there was to select from! Eugene noticed the small seam in the plastic and gave the metal tray a soft shake and felt his eyes go wide as the tray jostled softly backwards, revealing ANOTHER tray full of colored figurines, all assigned to a sport! Eugene leaned back and grabbed the box lid, the piece of compressed cardboard somehow containing all the information they needed to know how to play the game. He scanned the rules again and then found more text hiding on part of the box he thought had been scraped off.

'Morphmanji tokens are one of the most important aspects of the game. Choosing a token and inputing the information into the console will act as your game-type selection, as well as determine your avatars for the game. Choose carefully, once a game is started, new avatars CANNOT be obtained!'

"Wow..." The overweight geek said, drawing attention away from a rather emasculated looking Peter that was currently cartoonishly pinned beneath Judy's butt and back to the game.

"Oooooh, whatcha find there, Genie?" Lindsey cooed as she crawled from her beanbag where she'd spent thel ast couple of minutes laughing and instead plopped herself next to Eugene, making no effort at all to maintain social distancing as she LEANED into him and reduced the mostly eloquent nerd into a red, stuttering mess.

"I, um, uh f-found more, um, pieces if we wanna, if we wanna um, you know, play a different set of s-sports" He gibbered, his eyes flicking this way and that as he tried to focus on anything other than Lindsey's impossibly cute face.

'Ugh don't get a boner don'tgetabonerdon'tgetaboner' He thought frantically, and tried not to sigh in relief as Lindsey eventually turned away to inspect the pieces for herself as Judy and Peter untangled themselves on the couch.

"SELECT AVATARS AND PRESS START" The game unexpectedly buzzed once more, catching the young adults off guard. Eugene could have sworn it sounded...annoyed? Or maybe just impatient? But unless it was programmed like that, and the voice was certainly synthetic enough that it sounded like it came from an old Speak'n'Spell, there was no way it could be, right?

"Bleh, seriously do NOT like how loud this thing is" Lindsey grumbled, "So, like, what do we wanna play? Basketball, Baseball? Hockey? Oh what about this game with these cute horsies!" The skinny yet spunky sorority member reached into the second tray and pulled out game pieces that were clearly associated with Polo and showed them to the group.

"Bleh, horses stink. They smell like ass and they spit" Peter groaned as he continued to eye the football figurines.

After a riveting discussion which was momentarily paused so the group could get a handful of drinks and some light snacks to hold off the late afternoon hunger pangs, the students finally decided to play as...
1432.title: Immersive

15.content:
Before Eugene could put mind to keyboard, beefy tanned hands pulled the machine away from his hands.

“Who made this?” asked Peter, lifting up the geodesic dome of the game. “Makes me think ‘a one of those Speak n’ Spells, just, uh giant.”

“Ah, be careful,” pleaded the board’s owner, hands haltingly reaching towards his property. “It feels really, really fragi— wait a sec.”

A flash of white had caught Eugene’s eye as the jock, now conscious of his friend’s discomfort, gingerly lowered the gizmo. “What is it, dude?”

“Uh, can you just, like, lift it up a smidge again?”

Peter complied with no effort at all, hoisting the board well above everyone’s heads. Eugene snuck under the machine and started scraping at its bottom with a fingernail.

“You gonna tell us what you’re doing, Geno?” asked Peter. “‘cuz I don’t really want to do this all day. I mean, I could, but board games are, uh, a preferable alternative.”

“Yeah what’re you, like, doin’ Genie?” piped up Lindsey.

“There’s a- come on you—. Ugh. Hey Judy, you have fingernails, right?”

“Sure do.” responded the goth, flashing her black talons. “What needs slicing?”

She padded over to the raised contraption, and, realization dawning on her face, started scratching assiduously.

Peter lowered his head beneath the board. “Are you guys gonna tell us what’s going on?”

“Be silent, man-slave,” commanded Judy. “Half rations for talking back!”

Lindsey giggled as Peter raised his half-annoyed, half-amused head back above the board. After a few minutes more of conversationless scraping, Judy let out a squawk of triumph.

“Got it!”

“So, can I put this down now?” complained Peter.

“Sure you can, you poor baby.” crooned Judy in response. Boyfriend and girlfriend settled back onto the couch, the latter stroking her lover’s bicep after tossing something quickly to Eugene.

“Genie, what is ittttt,” whined Lindsey, sidling close and propping her elbows on Eugene’s knee — far too close for the geek’s comfort. “You’re all mysterious n’ stuff and I wanna knooooooooow.”

Eugene kept his gaze firmly eye-level and adjusted his eyeglasses nervously. “I, uh, there’s- underneath th’ board, there was— taped to it, really, so I —”

As his cheeks grew redder and redder with every syllable of incomprehensible babbling, Eugene just shoved a white piece of card-stock into her hands and turned away, punctuating his embarrassment with a mumbled “Notecard.”

(Judy whispered into Peter’s ear while the other two were looking away, the current-couple sharing a surreptitious chuckle.)

Lindsey’s eyes roamed over the paper, reading the supernaturally neat script aloud for the room.

To whomever this probably concerns,
Heya! If you’re reading this now, you probably have excellent taste, or you just like looking at the bottom of random game boards, you weirdo!
So I’m supposed to keep things interesting or whatever, so I added in a buncha modes for you?
Just give ‘em a type, I’m sure that you might maybe possibly potentially concievably like them!
~U.

P.S. ;)


Following the messages was a list of small letters that trailed off to the bottom of the card.

“Did you have to read ‘winky face’?” asked Judy, a contoured eyebrow curved with doubt.

“So these are, like, custom game modes?” pondered Peter. “They might be zanier than the default ones it came with.”

“I don’t remember seeing this before,” murmured Eugene, lost in thought. “Kinda curious to see what some of these do.”

“We can, like, restart it if they’re boring too, so, go for it, Genie!” cheered Lindsey, pumping an enthusiastic pink-nailed fist in the air.

“Alright, how about we try…?”

1511.title: Immersive

15113.content:
The four friends suddenly found themselves flying...literally flying...through a tunnel of long lights. As they went flying, they heard the following song being sung:

From out of the East a stranger came
A law book in his hand, a man
The kind of a man the West would need
To tame a troubled land
'Cause the point of a gun was the only law
That Liberty understood
When it came to shooting straight and fast
He was mighty good

Then the lights in the tunnel disappeared, and all was darkness.

When the lights came back on, the four friends found themselves in different places.

Eugene found himself riding in a stagecoach, looking out across a prairie. In the distance he saw a ranch house, but otherwise the prairie was empty..

Inside the stagecoach were two other people. One was a sleeping older man, who looked to be a merchant of some sort. The other was a man wearing the very stiff collar of a frontier preacher.

Eugene had a law book sitting on his lap, and he knew that on top of the stagecoach, he had bags full of other books as well as clothes. Eugene knew he was wearing a suit that was the latest fashion in New York City, but would get him labeled a "dude" in the frontier town of Bone Creek, where Eugene was heading at the moment.

Eugene knew his body was made lean and strong from growing up on a farm in upstate New York, but that he had none of the practical skills needed on the western frontier. But he was heading for Bone Creek because the town was booming, and needed a good attorney.

Standing on the porch of the ranch house in the distance was Pete. Pete knew he was the oldest son and the right hand man of the biggest rancher in the territory. Pete knew he couldn't read beyond a second grade level, but he excelled in all those practical skills of a frontier rancher, including gunslinging.

In the nearby town of Bone Creek, Judy (whose busty body had trimmed up a little, as well as lost all its tattoos, piercings and nail color) was the local dressmaker, and her father owned the adjoining mercantile store. Across town, Lindsey, whose hair was now simply blonde, was the new young school marm. Lindsey and brown haired Judy wore their hairs in tight buns.

Instilled in all four of the players' brains was that the first thing they needed to do is find the other players, and incidentally, not get killed in the process. They knew that they were currently in tutorial mode, and so lost lives wouldn't count against them, whatever that meant. And they knew more rules and their ultimate goal would be explained to them when they are able to get together, and at that point the "real" game would begin. Beyond that, they had no idea what was going on.

(Which player will we follow to watch the story unfold?)

152.content:
"GAME TYPE: SIMULATION. PLEASE CHOOSE SUBTYPE:

“Simulation?” Peter wondered aloud. “Is this, like, Madden or something?”

“No, it’s, uh…. different,” murmured Eugene, who was more interested in the options than conversation.

“Vivid description, Geno,” laughed Judy. “Hey, Lindz, could you wrangle some info outta him?”

Lindsey snapped into a smart salute and lurched up from her beanbag and minced over to the nerd, leaning over to get a better look at the screen.

“Oh! It’s, like, real-life stuff! Like Life!” chirped the rainbow-haired nerdette. “Uh, the board game.”

“So we can pretend to live life while we’re stuck at school. Neat.”

Judy gave her boyfriend’s pec a long-nailed flick. “Don’t be a dick, Petey.” She turned to Eugene with a big smile. “I’ve been playing a ton of Sims lately. Even made some based off of you guys.” She wiped a mock tear from her mascaraed eye. “It’s a shame that Peter the First drowned.”

“Hey, I saw you delete the pool ladder.” whined Peter, poking his girlfriend’s side with a thick finger. “I call foul play.”

“You can’t prove anything.”

Eugene and Lindsey watched the couple mock-fight with smiles, shaky and merry respectively. The slightly-paunched nerd gave a quick cough to draw everyone’s focus back to the entertainment thing-a-majig, “Funnily enough, there is an Education category. And Career. And Strategy.”

“One of these things is totally not like the other.”

Eugene scratched the back of his head with a grin. “Yeah. This ‘U’ person was just probably trying to fill options. Still, I think they’re neat.” He waved at the gently whirring box. “Any preferences?”

Peter’s bulky arm shot up first. “Strategy. I don’t wanna think about school while we’re at it, and thinking about job-stuff makes me all twitchy.”

“Poor widdle nervous top-seed athlete,” cooed Judy, lightly kissing her boyfriend’s cheek. “I kinda wanna see what Education is. Either it’s gonna be some schlocky edutainment stuff or it’ll be so realistic that we can pretend that the pandemic never happened.”

“That’s like, the falsest dichotomy I’ve ever heard,” giggled Lindsey. “Career sounds so totally neat-o! I can give you all, like, a sneak-preview of the millions I’m gonna make.”

The room turned to Eugene, who was expecting to be an instrument of democracy rather than the chooser himself.

“A-alright, I think we should try the…”
152.title: Simulation.

1521.content:
Eugene typed in ‘Education’ with a few light touches on the keyboard and not-inconsiderable flourish. Judy was kinda right about the schlock, and he had a bit of a soft spot for hamfisted learning-games — elementary computer lab had kinda forced that.

‘SUBTYPE SELECTED: EDUCATION’ droned the metal box.

“Ha! Looks like I have the best taste.” cheered Judy.

Peter frowned. Sure, he wasn’t one of those dumbass, frat-party jocks — despite his best attempt at being the latter part — but playing a game that purported itself as ‘Educational’ was not his best idea of a good time. Still, if Judy was happy, he was; and judging by the black-painted smile being aimed at him, she was.

“You’re more of a nerd than a goth, babe,” he murmured, planting a kiss on the top of her purple-locked head.

“Hey!” squawked Judy, lightly slapping her boyfriend’s arm. “I’m the ideal goth!”

“Uh, guys?” Eugene’s voice cut through yet another playful couple fight. “There’s, uh, a ‘Scenario Choice’ next.”

He read the screen as the room listened intently, Peter trying his very hardest not to yawn.

15211.content:
Eugene selected the first option with a nervous smile that slid quickly into a grimace when the game’s angry-robot synth voice droned ‘SCENARIO: CLIQUE A-CADEMY SELECTED.

Peter answered his nerd friend’s grimace with his own. “The word ‘clique’ is kinda putting me off, dude. I had enough of that stuff in high school.”

Judy, taking note of Eugene’s shamefilled slouch, lightly punched her boyfriend for the nth time that day. “It’s a game, Pete. There’s probably gonna be, I dunno, popularity points and crush-meters, not drama and social schisms.” She turned to Eugene with a sunny smile on her purple-makeuped face. “I think it’s neat, Eugene.”

“I think it’s totally awesome too!” Lindsey effused. “And mayb—”

A horrible screeching noise that sounded like a crowbar being put into a meat grinder interrupted any conversation the group might have had in favor of clapping their hands over their ears. After ten seconds of robot-snuff soundtrack, a latch clicked open delicately, unveiling an armada of molded plastic pieces.

“Whoa!” marvelled Judy as she picked up a miniature plastic apple red as blood. “Is this a 3D printer or something?”

“I… uh, don’t think so,” muttered Eugene, closely examining what appeared to be a yellow pom-pom. “This thing looks like it was made in the late eighties, I don’t think —”

“Actually, Genie, 3D printers were totally invented in the eighties,” cooed Lindsey, who was holding a small purple plastic studded collar. “The patent, like, ran out three years ago, or sumthin’.”

“Huh. Sorry for the doubt, Geno, this is pretty cool.” admitted Peter, who was admiring a blue football game piece. “I feel like this piece really gets me.”

“So, uh, there’s a mode selection next,” Eugene began, gesturing vaguely at the ‘Traditional’ and ‘Immersive’ buttons. “I think the tra—”

“Hold it!” declared Judy, rising from her boyfriend-nook. “We can’t be boring with the trial run!” An accusatory finger was leveled at Peter. “Especially you, mister. Not everything’s about sports and muscles!”

“Didn’t hear you complaining after game night, babe.” Peter curled an impressive tanned bicep and leered at his now-flushing girlfriend.

“No distractions, sweetie,” she coughed, small smile contrasting her furrowed brow. “Let’s try something different!”

She made a circuit around the room, plucking the molded plastic out of each student’s hand with surprisingly nimble gestures, considering the ballast she was carrying. “No football for you babe, and no excellent fashion accessory for me!” She laid the reclaimed game pieces on the table and resumed her seat next to her boyfriend.

“alsoican’tbethecheerleader.”

The whole room levelled incredulous gazes at Judy, who was three seconds short of whistling innocently.

Peter was the first to speak, though he kept it brief. “You?!”

Judy tucked a purple strand of hair behind her ear, rolling her eyes as she did so. “I didn’t come out of the womb with purple hair, Petey, jeez. It was a brief stint in highschool, my mom said I should do it, blah blah blah — I quit junior year! Too much vapid pushup-bras-pushing and social-status boyfriends for me.”

“I can kinda picture it,” pondered Lindsey. “You’re like, a natural brunette, right?”

“You can tell?! Ugh, I need to get this dyed again once salons reopen,” whined Judy, pulling a lock of purple out.

Realization dawned on Eugene, and a shaky grin spread across his face. “T-this isn’t an attempt to avoid getting the pom pom, r-right, Judy?”

Judy shuffled in her seat, face utterly placid.

“Wow, Jude, didn’t know you sink to such depths,” tutted Peter in mock disapproval. “And now that your most heinous crimes have been revealed, I’ll take my prize…” He reached towards the football, eyes gleaming.

“It’s true, Petey! Three years of ‘Sis Boom Bah”!” Judy whined, bapping his stretched arm uselessly. She cast a look at the room and, upon finding no allies, let out a sullen huff. “Babe, if we try new things this game, I’ll get my Fashion friend to sew me my old uniform.”

Peter’s arm froze halfway to the board and returned back to his side with lightning-fast speed. “You know guys, despite her twisted web of lies, Judy does make some excellent points.”

Lindsey rolled her eyes, bright smile on her face. “Like, whatever you say, pervo.”

‘SUBTYPE SELECTED: OCCUPATION’ intoned the old box..

“Yayyyy, Genie!” cheered Lindsey, rising from her beanbag perch and sashaying over to Gene, who fear/awaited a possible hug…

Gene politely averted his eyes from the denim-clad rear in front of him and stammered a “S-sure.”

Peter generally just nodded at all of her theoretical-relationship gushing, but he secretly hoped that Geno would work up the courage to ask out the rainblonde for coffee or something.

The chubby nerd could use a boost in confidence, maybe it’d get him to the gym.

Hey, maybe they could spot each other!

But fantasies of cute couples, workout buddies, and theoretical boardgame coding were dispelled from the minds of the common-rooms group as a harsh, mechanical, “SELECT SCENARIO’ intoned.

Lindsey stood over the keyboard for a few seconds before relinquishing it with an ‘Oof’ as she slumped back onto her keyboard. “You should choose, Genie.”

Gene took his place over the keyboard once more, taking a second before selecting…

"The goal for you, is to gain the promotion fastest...."

Lindsay shrugged, not terribly interested in the game.

"Is this the best?" she asked. Eugene less than impressed with her silence before the selection was made continued on.

"So, which do you prefer?" he directed his question to Judy. "Immersive or Traditional?"

"Let's see what it can do, and push it to it's limits... Immersive." She answered, finishing with a deliberate nod of her head.

Eugene shifted the controls so that 'Immersive' was selected.

"Ready?" he asked looking around the various friends, ensuring everyone had their controller. Lindsay already looked on the verge of dropping it, and throwing the game. Peter looked like he'd have preferred a more sports based game.

He decided to start the game before any objections were raised.

Stabbing the 'Start Game', a chip-tune emerged from the games system, and it started a countdown. Eugene frowned, not expecting it needed to load any levels, or even be capable of such complexity.

But, as he looked around, he suddenly spotted his hands instead of gripping the controller were turning to dust. The various particles only loosely held in place. The murmur of panic told him, that his friends had noticed too. The next moment, the dust started to race towards the screen. Drawing more of his arm into the dusty flurry, before reaching his body. His scream was cut out, as his chest was overrun by the ... the whatever... His thoughts still jumbled and terrified. Eugene was trying to lean back, further and further to avoid this. But as it reached his face, Eugene's vision went blank.

- - - - -

Bodiless, he felt himself thrown wildly about. Ricochetting around invisible corners, or drawn down some twisting wire. The sensations stopped before he could analyse it better.

He was back in the real world... Or, if it was the game one, it was very impressive. No longer where he was, his eyes darted wildly around. Ignoring the other people, he took only a few moments to realise he was in an office... Well, the tea room. The kettle clicked off, and he spotted the four mugs sitting ready for the boiling water.

It was about this moment, as Eugene wanted as much normality as possible. He reached out to pour a mug for everyone he spotted the feminine hand reaching for the kettle. His own hand. Twisting his wrist this way and that, Eugene confirmed it was a woman's hand... and following his gaze up that arm. He found a slender shoulder, and the unmistakable bulge of his bust.

Rather disconcerting from this angle. She felt her heart race...

Pouring the water, the air filled with the unmistakable aroma of coffee.

"I'm Eugene..." he said, his voice now trilling.

"I can't be a secretary!? I don't know what the heck those do?" Peter said in a minor panic making his high voice squeak even higher. Judy rolled her eyes at her boyfriends remark, "Secretary's aren't aliens, they're people. It's just a job. You sit at a desk, answer emails, take calls, maybe type out or organize projects you're given."

"Yes, we should be able to take in some context clues once we get to our desks. For example," Eugene said as he looked at an ID he had just noticed in his pocket. "I am indeed...Jeanie and I'm a secretary in the R&D department of Morphmanji Inc."

The other three fished for their ID's and saw they were all in the same department. Peter groaned as he saw his name was indeed Petra and was a little weirded out that he found the picture of the woman on the ID insanely hot. "So...we just go to our desks and...do stuff. And then we'll be out of here and back in our bodies?"

"Not necessarily, who knows how long it could take us to get promoted. It could take in game months or even years to get the promotion. We might even get a game over if we screw up enough. See," Lindsay said pointing at her ID. "In tiny print on the back of the ID it says '5 lives'. Maybe if we screw up 5 times we get a game over and who knows what happens then."

Peter gulped as his eyes widened in terror. His girlfriend noticed her boyfriends distress and Judy put an arm around Peter's shoulder and said, "Don't worry, I'll help you out so you don't have to find out what happens if we lose...but I'll still kick all of your butts." "It probably won't be that bad, I'm sure time will probably fly by as we play like in any real game." Eugene said to cheer everyone up, "It'll be just like doing homework!" He added enthusiastically and Lindsay nodded in agreement. Judy and Peter didn't share the same love of homework as the two nerdier members of their group, but didn't want to rain on their parade. Now that the 4 had settled down and into this world a little bit more, a clock went off implying the tea break was over. The four players went to their starting stations behind their desks which were conveniently all beside each other and right outside of the break room.

Before Peter could even sit down he heard the mad tapping of computer keys from Eugene and Lindsay's stations. I'm not really that good of a singer" He mumbled as he tried not to be overwhelmed by the perky blonde who was now setting her entire grinning head on his knee. 152421.content:

"Yeah, who even knows what it would be like anyway. How would you get 'Immersive' with like, a karaoke machine anyway?" Lindsey nodded in agreement.

The two males were either too busy getting cozy with/ogling their crushes to really do anything by mutter in agreement.

"Okies!" Lindsey bent over in front of Eugene and pressed the large black button that had 'Traditional' stenciled on it, pushing it back down into the machine which began whirring and clacking. Lindsey leaned back and without warning began lowering herself down towards Eugene's chair, and the overweight nerd as forced to sit up straighter and scooted back as the skinny blonde's small booty plopping down between his legs. Then the blonde LEANED back and rested up against Eugene's flab, and the geek was reduced to a reddening mess that was desperately trying not to pop a boner into Lindsey's back. The rainbow-blonde pushed herself further onto Eugene as she stared innocently at the machine as it processed.

"I wonder if we'll need, like, microphones or something though? I've, umm, got a couple of headset up in my room..." She wondered out loud, scooting back just a hair more and trying not to break character as she felt her toy tense up even more from the slightest touch. But then the machine chittered to itself for a moment before there was a loud SPROING and four small cylinders rose slowly from the game's plastic surface, each with a small, grid lined globes.

"Dude, this thing had microphones built into it!" Peter exclaimed in amazement, "Geno, this thing is so cool. I wonder what else it can do?"

"Who knows, but right now..." Lindsey popped up from her seat and Eugene visibly, if silently, relaxed as she collected the four audio input devices. She turned and handed one to Eugene, giving his tomato-red face a playful wink before bouncing around the coffee table and handing two more to Peter and Judy...Who fixed her friend with a knowing look, and receiving a quick stuck out tongue in return.

"Okay...I think we're ready? I wonder what do we do now?" Peter said, and in return the game buzzed once more, a tiny screen near the middle of the machine blinking 'TV INPUT REQUIRED'.

"Huh? Oh..." Lindsey looked at the currently off TV that hung on the dorm wall. The students hadn't turned it on in the weeks since the Pandemic hit, mainly because all it played were the local news station, the college news station, and CNN. With a shrug, shepicked up the machine, letting out a quiet 'oof' at the deceptively heavy chunk of plastic and moved it over to the inactive television.

"Do Eugene, do you, um, have any adapter cables? I think we need to run some AV cable through a co-ax and then use my HDMI adapter to fit it into the back here" Lindsey said, setting the game machine down on the shelf that sat under the TV and was filled with such educational VHS titles as 'The Economic Process of the Soviet Union circa 1974' and a well used DVD of 'Shrek 2' that clearly hadn't been moved for at least four years.

"Huh? I mean..." Eugene blinked dumbly at Lindsey's question. What was a co-ax cable? And then even MADE adapters for the old red/yellow/white cables? But he didn't want to look stupid and was about to answer when the TV flickered on by itself.

"WOAH!" Lindsey cried, taking a step back from the machine in caution while similar noises came from her three friends. After a moment of flickering, a pixelated logo appeared on the flatscreen, a twisting map of pathways the curved in and around each other before terminating into a empty circle in the middle, within which were the words 'Morphmanji Entertainment System'. The TV speakers spat out a short, very chip-tune-esque fanfare before two more buttons popped up on the machine's surface, and Lindsey could have sworn she hadn't seen any openings or any grooves in the plastic that may have appeared to be an opening.

On them were the word "Head to Head" and "Team Game". The blonde relayed this information to her friends.

"Well, I kind of wanted a team game..." Judy said, curling a finger around Peter's ripped abs, staring up at him dreamily.

"Hmmm, maybe since you and Eugene can't, like, sing, maybe we should do, like, Head to Head so me and Judy get to play against each other?" Lindsey said with a smirk.

"Hey!"

"Sorry Petey, but I've heard you sing in the shower, you're no Whitney Houston" Lindsey stuck her tongue out again, and Peter just shared a look with Judy and Eugene. Judy scrunched her face into a dramatic scowl for a moment, before giving Peter a nod and a shrug, breaking out into a smirk. Eugene simply looked away, not wanting to answer.

"CHOOSE GAME TYPE" A accented female voice said from the TV speakers, and after a moment, the group chose...

There was NO way that this was a mass produced game, this had to be someone's personal invention or something, the technology of the 80s (which was when the game had collectively assumed the contraption had been built) wasn't refined enough to fit into such small spaces. And then the mysterious power source it had...And how it somehow interfaced with a modern television without any form of input. All of this had to be custom made...And that just made her engineer senses tingle even more. "Maybe..." Eugene shrugged after a moment of thought. He looked at Lindsey, and for a moment he thought he saw something else behind those normally bright blue eyes, something that momentarily betrayed her typical flightiness...But then it was gone, and her eyes glittered with the playful mischief that he'd been stuck by the moment the nerd had first met her. The ice-blue TV screen flickered with numbers, with bold-texted ratings categories headed by the titles Player One and Player 2; bold-fonted of ‘PERFORMANCE,’ ‘APPEARANCE,’ and ‘MUSICALITY,’ sending a current of insecurity through Eugene.

“S-sorry Lindz,” he mumbled, casting a rueful gaze at his microphone. “I guess I’m the anchor here, huh?”

Lindsey, though buzzing from the residual energy of the performance, spared Eugene a sympathetic look. Quickly, she pulled the cute dork into a side-hug, bright smile on her face. “Don’t worry ‘bout it, Genie, it’s one of those Morton’s Fork thingies! Either you mess it up a ‘lil, cuz you’re, like, a guy n’ all, or you do it perfectly, but give up that super-nice baritone…”

The rainbowette let out a cheerful titter and circled a finger on the back of the nerd’s neck as the nerd himself hunched his shoulders and blushed even harder, a shaky smile on his face. Judy and Peter elbowed each other conspiratorially, small smiles on their face. These were good team-choices — mostly for their real-life shipping desires.

The scores meanwhile, had bloop-ed itself upon the screen, Player One’s score lined with a pleasing repetition of the alphabet’s first vowel, the only exception a B+ for Appearance — “Guess you can’t fake the K-Pop look!” Lindsey giggled.

Player Two had a much less impressive record. D-’s abounded for the guilty geek, with Appearance a dismal F. Eugene sagged remorsefully, and Lindsey attempted to comfort him with another side-hug — teasing the cutie-pie with a full-on fronthug seemed a bit rude right now.

The final score: a C displayed itself proudly on the screen, and Eugene’s face loss a degree of guilt. “That’s, uh, not as bad as I thought it would be…” he murmured.

“Yeah!” cheered Lindsey, slapping the geek playfully. “We can, like, pick a BTZ song or whatever next — something guy-y to let you really shine!”

Judy shifted in her chair. “I didn’t see many boy-groups there,” Peter cast an aspersive eyebrow at his girlfriend. “You know Alison — she’s 'stans Kpop’ or whatever they call it. It's all she talks about.”

Lindsey pouted. “Oh. That sucks.” Brightly, she skipped towards the dorm’s halls, towards the communal kitchen. “Need some water!” was the explanation shot behind her as her rainbow mane disappeared from view.

An awkward silence hung in the room as the words ‘TALLYING MISTAKES’ blipped across the screen.

Peter coughed. “You know, Gene, you don’t hafta be all torn up about this — it’s Karaoke, it’s supposed to be fun, so you should reall— OOF”

“What Mr. Insensitiv-o was trying to say, Eugie,” started Judy with a smile, removing her elbow from her boyfriend’s gut, “is that you don’t need to worry about ‘being an anchor’ or whatever. It’s your game, Lindsey’s having fun, and, more importantly, she’s having fun with you.”

“Plus, MEGATORCH,” Peter cut in, accentuating his ‘band’s’ title with a metal-esque growl, “,is gonna kick your guys’ ass, so don’t stress about futzing it all up.”

Eugene gave the mismatched couple a smile. It was a good thing that he hadn’t judged this duo of books by their respective covers — and maybe he did have a shot with Li—

Any musings of emotional honesty were interrupted by a red glare on the screen, the intimidating words ‘PENALTY CALCULATED’ underscored by ‘SELECT PLAYER TO RECIEVE APPEARANCE PENALTY’. The horizontal buttons on Gene’s held and Lindsey’s discarded microphones pulsed gently.

Peter scratched his coiffed head. “Yeah, what is an appearance penalty, anyways?”

“Maybe it’s a permanent score debuff—” hazarded Eugene, before catching the blank look of uncomprehension on the couple’s face. “Uh, a penalty subtracted from your appearance-score-weight every round.”

“That makes sense,” Judy said, mischievous grin on her face. “You could give it to Lindz — she’d never know…”

“Dick move, JuJu,” Peter scolded. “Gene might as well take it on the chin; don’t think he can really get more, uh, K-pop-y. Might as well make this as fair as it can be instead of a curbstomp symphony.”

Eugene vacillated between the two options — leaning towards taking it on himself, it was his fault after all — before…

WAIT.

It was coming from the pile of black tresses on the floor, a pile connected to a well-filled-out short and tartan skirt. After a few more seconds of despondent moaning, Peter staggered to his heeled feet, arms delicately laced across his stomach, as if he was about to be sick.

“It’s fuckin’ broken!” he wailed, his high voice ragged with despair. “I can’t see my goddamn feet past these and I’m a pipsqueak and it’s broken!”

Staggering under the weight of his anguish — and also on the stiletto heels — Peter kneeled down and buried his face into his soft arms.

Lindsey gnawed at her lip as her feminized friend quavered at the edge of tears. Sure, it was kinda definitely his fault, but… she’d be pretty upset if she was a guy, bleugh.

But before she could try to awkwardly comfort him — uh or should it be her now? — her lap’s occupant surged to her feet, face cherry-red with anger.

“병신!” she screamed, black hair swirling around her head. “병신!” she repeated, one hand snagging a pillow and whipping it at the prone Peter, who only let out a forlorn squeak in response.

Lindsey quickly got up and held Eugene’s hand back from slapping, whispering “It’s alright,” into her ear as the enfemmed geek’s angry cries slowly dissolved into a sobbing wail.

“Uh, guys?”

The sad and sadder members of the room turned towards Judy, who was backlit by the white gleam of the TV, the words TAKE FIVE: 1:58:41,’ slowly ticking down.

Judy chuckled sheepishly. “I just pressed the POWER button, guess it was rebooting or someth—”

She was interrupted by the bone-quaking jolt of Peter’s flying hug and the accompanying hailstorm of jawbone-kisses — Peter was a pipsqueak, after all — and ‘iloveyou’s. The goth shakily smiled through her potentially bruised ribs and lightly patted her boy-cum-girl-friend’s slight back.

Lindsey combed her mind to find the Korean term for ‘everything’s alright now,’ or a similar mollifying statement, but the wide smile she was met with assured her that the screen’s message had gotten across.

Girl hugged new-girl in the commons and vice versa, relief suffusing throughout their bodies.

That is, until Lindsey spoke up again. “So, uh, what happened?”

She was met with three pairs of inquisitive eyes, a sum that did not decrease as she translated the question for Eugene.

“I mean, that was some totally spooky stuff, right? So something must’ve happened.”

“I’m a chick now, Lindz, if you didn’t notice.” harumphed Peter, flopping back onto the couch.

Lindsey rolled her eyes. “Like, I’m talking about after you cried your eyes out, Petey-girl.”

Peter bristled at this and took a bluster-ready stance, but a gentle smile and pat on the shoulder from Judy stopped any aggressive overtures.

As Lindsey once again gave Eugene the Korean rundown on the conversation, Judy silently congratulated herself. All things considered, she was taking this pretty gosh-darn well.

There probably wasn’t a WikiHow article for ‘What to do When Your Boyfriend Loses A Foot-and-Change of Height and Gets a Cup Size or Two on You,’ but she could probably write it after this.

Step 1: Let her know you’re there for her.

Step 2: Try to stop her from exacerbating and/or perpetuating her new Napoleon Complex.

Step 3: Try to avoid any kisses without breaking her heart, because boy howdy do they make you feel uncomfortable.

Alright, Step 3 probably needed some work. Sure, he was a lot shorter now, heaps softer and definitely… lumpier, but physical attraction isn’t the most important part of romance, right? A lack of Eros wasn’t enough to put a hole in her Pragma-ship, right?

As Judy’s pride turned into self-doubt, one of her fidgety peep-toed feet bumped into an unfamiliarly textured object: some kind of bumpy vinyl? Putting the adjacent-seated stewing runt out of her mind, she picked it up…

“Oh, shit.”

Lindsey afforded Judy a brief glance before turning back to her foreign-language conversation, but Peter gave the goth her full attention. In her girlfriend’s hand was a black, rippled-vinyl purse, the front upon which a rhinestone skull proudly sat.

Judy forced a smile onto her face. “I think this is yours, babe.”

Incredulity, fear, and indignation crossed Peter’s face all at once. “No,” she squeaked.

Judy’s patience wore a little thinner. “This isn’t mine, Petey, Lindsey doesn’t wear black, and Eugene’s whole… aesthetic isn’t really sk—”

“No way!” Peter screeched, before scooting awashe could. Pinprick pupils flicked from side to side before the stressed shorty grabbed a pillow and started screaming bloody murder into the polyurethane.

“무슨 일이 있어?” Eugene’s attention was piqued, first by her name, then by the series of wineglass-shattering cries.
“She sai—”

“I got the gist,” Judy faintly smiled, with a vague sense of concern around the pronoun-change. “I f— WE found Peter’s purse.”

“It’s not MINE!”

Judy ignored her. “Geno probably has one too. I’d guess…” She scanned the bewildered beauty’s ensemble. “... sequins. Or sparkles.”

Lindsey went to work translating as Judy rooted through the purse. A mix of amusement and creeping dread seeped into the goth’s smile as she felt through the bag. The little round disc had to be a compact and the little phone she felt definitely had more rhinestones on its back.

Peter inched closer as her girlfriend investigated, staring towards (though never quite at) the object, as if direct eye contact would blind her. In response, Judy fished out a bulky black wallet shot through with a rosebush pattern and tossed it to her beau.

Across the room, Lindsey and Eugene found the purse that was, indeed, covered with sequins. A passport for ‘Euna’ was located in sharp succession.

“My fuckin’ name is Petra?!”

Judy met Peter’s outrage with a gentle smile. “At least it’s close to Peter —” The sight of ‘Petra’s’ license gave her ample room for pause. Seeing a smile on her boyfriend’s new face just felt… wrong. The girl in the picture had less piercings, but she was still clearly mugging for the camera; her smile was pouted out a bit, and her eyes were half lidded.

Judy shuddered: this was weird.

Lindsey snorted from across the room. “I bet your height’s, like, 4’2”.”

“Fuck off Lindz,” Peter shot back. “Why don’t you grope your new girl-toy some more?”

Judy would have tried to play peacemaker, but she was busy stuffing the purse-sourced condom she had found into the recesses of the couch.

Lindsey let out an outraged scoff. “Wow, Petra. I thought the game turned you into a goth, not a total bitch.”

“Same to you, Micheals! We both know you’re gonna throw the next round, just to keep Geno nice and huggable!”

The sorority girl snapped to her feet, gently pulling the confused Eugene up with her. “Actually, I was planning on totally kicking your fat ass, Tziermos!” She raised a finger to her pursed lips in mock realization. “Oh wait, did your last name change too?”

That was enough for Peter. She shot to her feet — only stumbling a bit on the stilettos — and yanked Judy up behind her, the definite effort she had to expend only exacerbating her anger. “FUCK YOU!” she howled, body tilted forward like the force of her scream would knock Lindsey over.

The sorority girl remained standing, however, and flicked up a middle finger at the volcanic goth. “You too, shortstuff.” she sneered.

The two feuding girls stormed out of the room to their respective dorms with passengers in tow; one whispering a slew of rapid Korean and the other stunned into silence.
1524211111121133.title: Fight! Fight!

15242111111211331.content:
“Gawd, I can’t believe her!” Peter fumed. The staccato tik of her heels sounded like gunshots to Judy’s ears. “Har-de-har, I’m short; funny joke — well, you’re a bitch!”

“Yeah,” murmured Judy. Her mind was a million miles away. The surreality of the situation wasn’t just catching up to her, it had left her in the dust. She had been Peter’s girlfriend for a year, and never once had the burly jock been anywhere near that level of anger.

“him like a pet! Yeah, I thought she was bi or somethin', but, like, when Geno transformed, she… Hey, you there, Jude?”

He had laughed off the most venomous insults whispered behind his back, comforted her calmly after particularly harrowing parent-calls, and sure, he got a bit whiny when things didn’t go his way, but when the chips were down, he’d always be a rock, a stable —

“—ou alright? Ju-Ju?”

“Wha?” Judy blinked back to reality to have Peter’s round face fill her vision, her wide eyes made even more so by concern.

“You look pale, Ju — uh, paler than normal.” Peter raised herself to her tip-toes, an easy feat to accomplish given her boots, though it did only give her an extra half-inch. She laid a dainty hand on Judy’s forehead. “You don’t have a fever or anything, but we can skip the Battle of the Bands if you need it—”

A lump rose in the goth’s throat and she pulled her shrunken boyfriend into a tight hug, driving the breath out of Peter’s lungs with an inelegant squeak. “I just don’t wanna lose you,” she whispered hoarsely.

“I’m not going anywhere, babe,” Peter croaked, one hand lightly patting Judy’s back. “But, uh, this is real tight...”

“Oh!” Judy released her prisoner. Peter gratefully gulped down lungfuls of air, one dainty hand gently massaging her thin throat. Judy chuckled nervously. “Sorry.”

Peter smiled weakly. “S’ alright. Just, uh, something to get used to. And, hey, speaking of getting used to…” She scrunched her face into a mask of concentration, and with a deep breath, pulled herself into an impromptu pirouette. Judy gawped as Peter came to a halt, a few locks of hair stuck to the edge of a wide grin. “Tah-dah!”

“Wow, that’s…” Judy struggled against the sense of disquiet burgeoning in her head for the right word. “...impressive!”

“Yeah, right?” effused Peter, breathless. She bent over and traced the shapely length of one leg with a hand. “It’s just another kind ‘a exercise; there’s posture, core-engagement, the works!” A tuneless hum left her painted lips as she started off down the hallway again.

Judy followed her; an easy task considering Peter’s short stride. A silly thought crossed her mind, and she let out a short titter. “Maybe you should talk to the guys about working it into your training routine.”

Peter turned to her with a politely confused smile. “Hm?”

Judy was forced to confront the awful, painful reality of a failed joke. “I meant, uh, when you’re normal— imeanaguy again, you should, um, talk to the team about exercising with them…”

Peter blinked twice before offering a laugh that Judy was fairly certain was forced. “Oh. Ha! I get it.” Ostensibly to change the subject, she shrugged off the black strapped purse that Judy just noticed had been slung over her shoulder and held it out towards the flustered goth. “Hey, could you, uh, carry this? Think you might have bruised my ribs a ‘lil.”

“Yepsuremhm.” Judy snatched it quickly, her face flushing a shameful rosé.

Peter gave her a smile and bopped down the hallway, her nervous girlfriend closely following after.
15242111111211331.title: Mind Keeps on Slippin'

152421111112113311.content:
“God, I hate this.” moaned Judy.

“Eh, it’s kinda cool — in a way.” said Peter, brows lightly knit.

The two stood in front of Judy’s dorm room, or rather, Judy and Petra’s dorm room. Where before the entrance was relatively austere, the door now was more reminiscent of something Judy had seen at Lindz’s sorority. A whiteboard now sat proudly below the peephole, its rim slathered in purple glitter. ‘Judy R.’ sat on the left in bulky black letters, almost comically contrasted by Petra’s own signature, an ersatz purple mix between cursive and Webdings, with the enclosed bowls in ‘P’ ‘e’ and ‘a’ decorated with a cutesy miniature skull. Hell, if Judy didn’t know she was looking for a ‘Petra’, she’d be deciphering these hieroglyphics for ages!

Stickers flanked the right side of the whiteboard, running the gamut from caricatured calavera to an elaborate serpentine rosebush that must have been hell to get off the vinyl. A faux warning sign sits askew above the whiteboard, reading ‘BAD GIRLZ AHEAD,’ though its ragged edges speak of numerous attempts at removal. Its attacker seems to have given up after ripping their third corner, however, and settled for scribbling out the ‘Z’. Poorly.

Judy wasn’t sure how long she spent staring at the door, but an insistent rapping on her shoulder jolted her out of it. Peter peered sheepishly up at her. “Uh, do you have the key?” She twirled the hem of her skirt demonstratively. “No pockets here.”

It took only ten seconds to produce the key from the purse — decorated with another skull, much to Judy’s chagrin — but the buzz of movement from the bedazzled phone gave her pause. ‘Petra’s’ phone was tempting, but the device was definitely some kinda Pandora’s box…

Judy fished it out anyways as Peter fumbled with the lock, and stowed it in her skirt pocket. In for a penny, right?

“Is this, weird for you at all, Pete?”

Pete stopped with a moment to aim a major side-eye at her. “Not at all, Ju. It’s a funny coincidence, really; I was gonna ask you to saw off my legs at the knee, so I could be extra tiny. And later I was gonna staple a pair of milkjugs to my chest. Everything worked out; really.”

Judy wrinkled her nose at the term, but couldn’t help but laugh.

“Oh my god, never say that again,” she half-whispered, half-snorted, looking around like walls had ears, and maybe also Victorian sensibilities. Brushing a hand past her grin, she forced it into a stern line. “No, I mean, aren’t you taking this really well?”

But Peter smelled blood in the water. “Taking what well? These biggy-wiggy jubbly-bubblies?” She hefted her prodigious chest to clarify, lips curled into a smirk.

Judy, with her fairly sheltered upbringing, had not developed the immunity to ‘naughty words’ required for everyday life in the collegiate world.

“Peter Tzerimos, that is disgusting!” she scolded, though the way scandalized giggling punctuated nearly every syllable didn’t do much for her authority.

Peter’s bottom lip wobbled dramatically, twisting her delicate features into a Disney-worthy pout. When she spoke, her voice was high, quavering, and laced through with sorrow. “That’s messed up, Ju-Ju. Just ‘cuz I got a big ol’ pair of honker-bonker bongo-wongos doesn’t mean I’m not human.”

“Ohmigod stop”Judy gasped, her body bent double with laughter.

Her mirth was infectious: Peter’s faux-offense soon crumbled into a high, buoyant titter, a stark contrast to the booming guffaw he had a few hours before.

Their laughter graduated to a fit; Judy leaning on her beau’s slight, inkspattered shoulders for support, Peter clinging to Judy’s biceps for the same reason.

It was a long minute before their giggling came to a stop, though smiles still split either girl’s mouth.

“My stomach hurts.” coughed Peter, one hand moving to curl around her midsection.

“Me too.” murmured Judy, gazing into Peter’s ice-blue eyes.

Peter coughed politely.

Judy squeezed her shoulder affectionately.

Silence hung in the hall.

Then Judy suddenly, impulsively, pulled Peter into a kiss.

Judy had kissed two people in her life. The first was the boy she had taken to her school’s Spring Formal, Hank Paloma. Judy had really, truly, liked him, but the boy had only allowed the briefest lip-to-lip contact once, expressing concern that her lip might get stuck in his braces, the devils of temptation, etc. etc.

Two weeks later, he had written a long message to her on Facebook, explaining that he was, in fact, gay.

They agreed to stay friends.

The second person she had kissed was Peter, and those kisses were much better. The way he held her made her feel safe; how he never complained that her breath smelled, even though he made sure that his always smelled like peppermint; how at the beginning he always asked to make sure she was comfortable and… and…

It was nice.

This kiss was only marginally better than Hank’s.

Boobs were an issue: Judy had to stand on her tiptoes and crane her neck to avoid collision, and even then she had to arch her back a little bit to make sure that she didn’t frame Peter’s chin with her chest.

Also, his lips were way too soft now; it felt like she was pressed up against a pair of microwaved gummy worms that, for some reason, were liquorice-flavored.

Peter didn’t seem to know where to put her hands too, flailing them about in surprise as it first began, before carefully traveling to her hips, settling on them for a second before abruptly recoiling, either one hovering awkwardly around Judy’s body.

It was the eyes that were the worst, though, Judy thought. When the goth had pulled her sweetheart into the kiss, she had kept hers open for a second, just to see Peter’s pupils contract into pinpricks, spinning about in their sockets like a panicked animal. Judy had closed hers after that, but could still practically feel her gaze drilling into her.

Sure, it might have sucked, but she needed to do this. Peter was still Peter, no matter how small and soft. Judy Ross would make herself like girls with sheer force of will!

It had been twenty seconds: she’d up the ante. It was time to go for tongue. She summoned all of her gumption...

Then Peter pulled away, and Judy could feel her heart break.

“J-ju, I’m sorry. I just needed to breathe, it’s not you—”

Judy hoped that her smile looked genuine. “Don’t worry, Pete.”

“I just wasn’t ready, sorry,” Peter tucked a strand of hair behind an ear. “We can, uh,” A flash of discomfort flit across her face. “... try again later.”

“Yeah, maybe.”

“I’m really sorry, Jay, I—

“Hey,” Judy took Peter’s hand in her own and squeezed. “It’s all good.”

Relief washed over Peter’s face. “Really?”

“Really.”

Peter smiled. “Good.” She coughed into her hand, probably to dispel the awkward air, and turned the doorknob with a flourish. “Let’s check out the digs, girlfriend~!”

Judy slouched in after her, noting that the term of endearment sounded distressingly platonic.
152421111112113311.title: Awkward Moments

choices: Judy doesn't quite know how to process this and bails.
1524211111121133111.content:
Judy walked in the room with far more dread than her companion, who seemed way too enthused with this identity-alienating situation. Part of the room was familiar; the same grey-sheeted bed, the desk with the assorted mythological treatises on its surface, and the partially full wardrobe, that contained mostly black-and-greys.

What was new, however, was the line of black-and-yellow caution tape in the centre, a stickynote placed at its end helpfully denoting it as ‘THE DMZ’.

What was even newer was entire other side of the room, the bed a vibrant (and eye-shattering) combo of neon yellow and bright pink, the wall adorned with posters — most containing women dressed similarly to Peter, band names beneath them in jagged metal letters. The few with guys on them all had their male subjects shirtless, and covered in some kind of oil and/or water, to Judy’s chagrin.

Judy cast a look at the desk. Framed pictures of ‘Petra,’ and… her. One of her and her enfemmed beau at some kind of concert, the former uncomfortably smiling whilst wrapped in a large overcoat, the latter in a scandalous fishnet bodystocking, the purple-and-black underwear underneath the only things keeping her decent.

Another one at a bar: Petra hoisting a pink cocktail glass and the photographing camera, aiming a prodigious pout at the lens. Judy had a glass of clear spirit to her lips and paid no heed to the camera. The photographed girl frowned. She hated candids.

Judy's stomach squirmed. This was fuckin’ weird. Sure, she had girded herself for the loads of Petra-paraphernalia, but the fact that they had her in it was a whole other can of dysphoric worms.

Peter, meanwhile, had bopped over to ‘her’ closet, more specifically, the full-length mirror on the door. beginning an impromptu investigation of her new face, poking and prodding her features with a black nail.

“Jee-zus, Jay, you shoulda told me about the mascara!” she whined. “Do you have any makeup wipes?”

“You probably do.” Judy mumbled, numbly sliding into her chair. Did Peter even know what makeup wipes were before?

The pilfered phone buzzed in her pocket, and Judy, hoping for a distraction but fairly certain that there was no way she’d find it on Petra’s phone, pulled it out.

It was an Instagram notification. ‘deezybroncos’ has liked your post!’ Morbid curiosity thrummed throughout Judy. She shouldn’t look; there was no way it was gonna make her feel any better; there were, like, fifty ‘like notifications’ from similarly weird usernames and she was already opening it.

Judy typed the code 0229 in with a rueful smile. Petey’s birthdate, and also Petra’s apparently, evidenced by the now-open phone. The big goof never really put much thought into his passwords and it looks like the little shortstaOH JESUS

The mortified goth let out a squeak. How couldn’t she?! Judy spared a look at Peter, and heaved a sigh of relief. She hadn’t heard her, embroiled in the act of daubing the streaks of mascara as she was.

Growing up as not-actually-the-preacher’s-daughter-but-pretty-close-to-that had left Judy with a tiny little bit of reservation towards… ‘lewd things’. Sure, she was all for body positivity, owning your own sexuality — heck, her own outfit featured a bit of cleavage — but other people doing it usually brought a blush to her cheeks. It wasn’t secondhand embarrassment or disapproval or attraction or stuff like that; it was just…

Alright, it was secondhand embarrassment, whatever. She couldn’t imagine doing stuff like… this. Anyways, she could feel the heat in her face: it was probably crimson now.

Petra’s account was dubbed ‘ghoulgurl’, the profile bubble featuring the girl snarling in black makeup, her hands raised on either side of her head, curled into claws. The bio read as such:

✧･ﾟ: *✧･ﾟ:* music major and part-time BTGGF at North Point *:･ﾟ✧*:･ﾟ✧
ppl who call me short get 🔪ed
:P


Vowing to look up what the hell BTGGF meant later, Judy scrolled through the profile, horror mounting. The posts were positively scandalous! One had Petra against a large granite pillar, wearing a tanktop that was more like a pushup bra with a hem, the bits below her exposed midriff wrapped in a way-to-goddamn-short pair of jorts and strategically ripped fishnets. There was more in the set: next featured Petra leaning towards the camera, slyly smiling as she tucked a lock of hair behind one ear, back bent to thrust out… ugh.

Judy flicked through a the similarly risque gallery before she noticed the description.

like if u wish u were the pillar ;)
credits:
camera: pilfered from the photo lab
(unwilling)photographer: @jdross

i have 2 get her coffee 4 a week now :(

A manic laugh escaped from her lips. Great. Fan-fucking-tastic. She was complicit in her boy-turned-girlfriend’s thirst trap, which netted… 2,357 LIKES?!

That was, like, a third of the people at North Point!

Judy shook off her shock and continued her dread investigation. Though they were very hard to look at, the posts did reveal quite a bit. Petra was in the Music Theory program, and was planning on minoring in Fashion Design, explaining the dizzying array of outfits she wore.

What wasn’t fashioned out of thrift store finds was apparently supplied courtesy of ‘Daddy’s credit card,’ which was thankfully not a euphemism for male-admirer’s-money. It was almost funny: many a time Peter had griped about how his dad never even gave him birthday money; apparently, Petra’s dad had looser pursestrings.

Judy hoped to God that Petra’s dad didn’t have access to this account, though. If he were anything like hers — a damming comparison for any parent — he’d have yanked the girl out of school the moment his follow request went through.

The most recent one was a prime example: Four days ago, Petra had apparently decided to get a tattoo at ‘Lovecraft Parlor,’ one of the few such establishments that was still open. The picture had Petra donning a skull-emblazoned facemask and lying down on a table swaddled with towels, her arm propped up on the same surface to display the new ink; a rosebush with skulls in the stead of blooms.

This would be all well and good if Petra wasn’t topless, and her festooned arm wasn’t the only thing preventing covering her Terms-of-Service-violating chest. Judy’s alternate-universe-counterpart seemed to share similar… reservations, as per the posts comment chain:

jdross: PETRA WHAT THE FUCK

ghoulgurl: :p whats the prob roomie? u jelyl? its the human body nuthin to be shaamde about

ghoulgurl *ashamed

jdross First off, you’re DEFINITELY drunk. Second off, pictures don’t just disappear off the Internet. There’s probably around a hundred people that posted this somewhere else the moment they sa… more

ghoulgurl: tl;dr. xd

“Hey, whaddya looking at?”

Before Judy could process the implications of the post, the phone was delicately plucked out of her hands by its now-makeupless owner, who had apparently seen fit to strip to her underwear.

Judy watched Peter flick through the phone, guilt burgeoning in her breast. “Petey, I —” But what could she say? ‘Oh, yeah babe, I was investigating your newly manufactured past: did you know that you’re a gothy ditz? Pret-ty weird.’

But Peter did not frown. Nor cry. Nor express any kind of animosity towards the soulcrushing, girlfriend-alienating existential rewriting. Instead, she lightly smirked, said “Huh, looks like you didn’t change at all,” with a giggle, and tossed the phone on her bed as she minced over to the closet.

Judy's mouth hung open. “What?”

Peter peeked at the flabbergasted goth from over her shoulder. “I mean, c’mon, J. That little spiel in the comments is, like, classic you.” Lightly tittering at her diss, she pulled a mess of straps and cups out of her closet. “Hey, we’ll get extra points for dressing up, right?” Without waiting for an answer, she waved the fabric monstrosity at the flabbergasted Judy. “Do you think this’d fit you? Second thought, it might be a little big...”
1524211111121133111.title: Best Friends Forever

choices: Peter concedes that there might be some trickery at work.
Peter remains in a state of (potentially magic-reinforced) denial.
15242111111211331111.content:
Judy put her foot down. Literally, with a heavy stomp, and idiomatically, with a loud, “ARE YOU FUCKING KIDDING ME?!”

Peter jerked back at the shout, bumping her head against the closet door. “Owwww,” she whined, rubbing a hand against the growing bump on her skull. “What’s your fuckin’ damage, Jay?”

“M-my damage? My boyfriend’s trying on new bras —”

“New tops.”

“New I-don’t-give-a-shits!” Judy stomped towards her topheavy sweetheart. God, did Pete even know that she planted her hands on her hips, or did that stupid board game… ugh.

She looked down at her boyfriend’s defiant blue eyes. Eyes that were normally a different color, and that she had to look up at, and were a lot smarter — whatever. This required a delicate touch, precision in word choice and an easy manner.

“Did the fuckin’ karaoke machine make you stupid or something?”

That wasn’t it. Another try, maybe—

“‘Cuz you’re, like, one-hundred-percent bimbo right now, seriously.”

Regret surged in Judy, but Peter’s feminine scoff of outrage quelled it a tetch.

“Oh yeah, I’m the bimbo, when you’re the one saying ‘like,’ y’ ditz.” Peter waved her hand dismissively in a manner that was so feminine that Judy was half-sure it was on purpose. “Gawd, you’re acting like Lindsey right now.”

Judy raised her hands in supplication. “It’s this shit! When the hell did you start hating Lindsey?! Three days ago you said she was cool!”

Peter crossed her arms, pushing her impressive prow up and out. “Sometimes, perspectives change, Jay. Like I said earlier, the moment Eugene got, uh, girled —”

“What about you, Pete?” Judy cut in, tears starting to pool in her eyes. “Do you think that maybe when you got zapped into Daria with F-cups, the Parcheesi board planted some kinda preppy-hatred in your brain?”

“I think that I’d be the first one to know, Ju.” Peter sneered.

Judy set her face into a line. “Fine. Close your eyes.”

“Why shoul—”

“CLOSE YOUR GODDAMN EYES, TZERIMOS.”

“Okay, Jesus.” Peter did so. There was a quizzical bent to her frown as she strained her ears, listening for clues to Judy’s ploy. Rustling fabric was the loudest noise: was she doing something with the bed?

Ugh, whatever.

Like, who the hell did Judy think she was? She just got like this sometimes, all concern-y and hysteric-y; it was a bit much sometimes.

It wasn’t a dealbreaker or anything: Peter wasn’t going to find a better BFF GF anywhere, but it was just so frustrating sometimes. Sure, she cried a bit at the start: losing a foot and, like, a bajillion muscly pounds was pretty tough for a girl to deal with.

But she adjusted pretty well, after the ‘Save and Quit’ nonsense. It could be way worse after all. She could have Eugene’s language problem, or — Peter’s frown twisted itself into a smug smirk — she could be a flatty like Lindsey.

(God, she’d rather jump out the second-floor window.)

“Juddyyyyyyy, can I look yet?”

“No! Can you hear yourself? I swear two hours ago, you’d be kicking yourself...”

Peter rolled her eyes, though it didn’t really work through her eyelids. Was it pick-on-Peter hour or something? If she didn’t know better, she’d say that Geno was dissing her in Korean! She’d get back at Little-Miss-No-Tits, though, by kicking her flat ass in karaoke.

She should try to get back at Jay: though nothing big, the girl had been through a lot. Plus, her boyfriend was wearing the whole goth shtick way better — wait, was Judy jealous? A sly smile lit up Peter’s face: she could work with this.

“Alright, I’m ready.”

Get Ju out of the room, get one of the outfits in the closet — there was some spicy stuff in there — and get some pics; nothing studio-quality, but it’d be enough. There had to be some guys in Gunners Butte still on dating apps, right? It’d be easy-goddamn-peasy to—

“PETER, OPEN YOUR DAMN EYES.”

Peter opened her eyes with a dramatic roll, leveling her gaze on Judy to give her the business… but instead, she had to bite back a snort. Judy Ross stood in front of her, stripped down to her skivvies; a totally embarrassing granny bra, embroidered with pink fabric flowers and a pair of nude-colored panties that made her look like a Hot-Topic Barbie.

“Whaddya think, Petey?” Judy asked, twirling her hips to showcase the fashion disaster. “Gimme your first impression: don’t hold back on my account.”

“You -snrk- look like a Victoria’s Secret retiree, Ju!”

“There! That’s th—”

“No, like an actor from an abstinence-education video!”

“Alright, I get i—”

“Is the brand line called Disappointment?!”

“Alright,” thundered Judy. The goth put her hands on the pipsqueak’s pale shoulders and locked her gaze on hers. “When, in our going-on-two-years of dating have you ever cared about how fashion-forward my underwear was?”
15242111111211331111.title: Judy gets mad.

15243.content:
After some intense discussion the group decided that neither 'Music' or 'Outdoors' were suitable choices, while Peter groaned once more about everything taking too long. But as Eugene went to type in 'More' on the game's small keyboard, the machine bleeped and immediately produced more options.

"Oooh, I wonder what 'Pets' are?" Lindsey held back a dirty thought and a giggle of her in latex and a whip and some KILLER heels while Judy and Eugene crawled around on the floor. Or at least Eugene's face on Peter's body, because while she liked Eugene the geek needed to lose some SERIOUS weight before he could fully be part of any idle fantasies. Especially if she was going in THAT particular direction. The mental image of Judy, however, was fine.

"Maybe it's like a pet store? Oh, maybe it's like that Nintendogs game! I played that when I was little, it was pretty fun!" Judy said with sudden glee, the happy memory flooding back in a wave of nostalgia. It had been in Sunday School and during a particularly boring day, in between the 'Praise Jebus!' and the other highly conservative rhetoric that implied she would burst into flames for even the slightest offense, a friend had let her play the cute little game. She had liked it so much that she had, somehow, talked her mom and dad into getting it for her. It had been the ONE video game she had ever owned, and one of the few she'd ever played before she'd escaped to college.

"What's the other one say? ...What the hell is 'Moderation'?" Peter squinted at the tiny red screen and scratched his head, "What, like 'drinking in moderation' or something?"

"That...is a pretty weird suggestion" Lindsey agreed, biting a already short nail as she tried to think of what it might have meant. It could have been what Peter had said...Or forum moderation? Twitch stream? She was suddenly reminded of that silly eGirl stream moderation game that had gotten canned recently. It could have been that, could it?

"Well, I can always see if it has anything else if no one feels like trying out these?" Eugene offered, hands poised over the keyboard.
